entry.title: SAP BTP Joule Setup Failure - Error
entry.content:
SAP BTP Joule Setup Failure - Error  

This document summarizes the issue encountered during the Joule setup in SAP BTP, including error details and screenshots for incident submission. 

 

Error Summary 

 

During the execution of the 'Setting Up Joule' booster, the process failed during SaaS Subscription creation. 

 

 

 

Error Message 

 

Unexpected state UPDATE_PARAMETERS_FAILED occurred while trying to create the subscription to application das-application-ias.  

 

 

 

Automation GUID 

 

4b22917f-c0a-4111-baee-2c5fe758647d 

 

Expected Behavior 

 

- The booster should successfully create the das-application-ias SaaS subscription. 

- All booster steps should complete and show green status. 

- Joule should become available for configuration within the subaccount. 

 

Actual Behavior 

 

- SaaS Subscription step failed with status UPDATE_PARAMETERS_FAILED. 

- Remaining integration steps were skipped automatically. 

- Joule provisioning never completed.  

 

 

 

 

Impact on System 

 

- Joule cannot be deployed or used in the current BTP landscape. 

- Subaccount provisioning is incomplete. 

- Further integrations depending on Joule cannot be configured. 

- Delays implementation timelines. 

 

Troubleshooting Already Attempted 

 

- Retried booster execution. 

- Validated entitlements (AI Core, AI Launchpad, Identity Services). 

- Checked IAS trust configuration. 

- Verified subaccount exists and is accessible. 

- No custom configurations that should interfere with SaaS subscription logic. 

 

Request to SAP Support 

- Investigate the UPDATE_PARAMETERS_FAILED error during subscription creation. 

- Validate the backend provisioning logs for automation request GUID 4b22917f-c0a-4111-baee-2c5fe758647d. 

- Confirm if any configuration or entitlement is missing for the target region.

entry.title: Statutory Reporting and EFD-Reinf: Mass Rectification for the R-4000 Series
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We're excited to share a new feature in the EFD-Reinf report for Brazil, specifically for users of the Statutory Reporting framework: Mass Rectification for the R-4000 Series. This enhancement is set to transform how you manage corrections for the EFD-Reinf R-4000 series.

Introducing Mass Rectification in R-4000 Series

With the new Mass Rectification functionality, users can now easily generate rectification files for multiple events at once during the Correction Phase of your reporting tasks. This means faster and more efficient handling of corrections when you need to rectify several events for a given company and branch.

How It Works

When running the Brazil EFD-Reinf Periodic Files task, you'll notice a new Run Mass Rectification checkbox in the selection criteria popup, as seen below:

Hereâ€™s what you need to know about the options:

  • File ID for Rectification:
    • When a specific File ID is entered in this field, the system will create the rectification file only for the provided File ID (i.e., only the selected event will be corrected). 
  • Run Mass Rectification Checkbox:
    • If you select the Run Mass Rectification flag without entering a File ID, rectification files will be generated for all eligible R-4000 series events for the specified Company Code and Business Place.
    • This is especially useful when multiple corrections are needed across several events, saving you significant manual effort!

Additionally, you can schedule or run this task immediately with the standard Run Options for background processing that is recommend for large volume of files, making it even easier to fit rectification into your processes.

Why Use Mass Rectification?

  • Faster Corrections: Generate rectification files for many events in a single run.
  • Greater Flexibility: Correct either specific events by ID or all relevant events for your company and branch at once.
  • Improved Compliance: Stay up to date with changing requirements and ensure your data is always accurate.

Learn More

To explore this new functionality and stay updated on further enhancements, check out these SAP Help Portal resources:

  • Document and Reporting Compliance
  • EFD-Reinf Report

 

We value your feedback!
If you have any questions or suggestions for future topics, please leave your comment below.

See you in the next post!



Statutory Reporting for Brazil Team

entry.title: Re: Individual usage record with allowance template
entry.content:
Hi Ankit, 

yes this is the expected behaviour. For scenarios where usage is rated individually, allowances are not considered. 
The reason is that usage records with rating type Individual can have items having quantity fields to be used for pricing, and there is no way to configure which quantity field is the relevant one to consider during allowance allocation. 

Meanwhile we improved the documentation as previously this piece of information was not easy to find.

Best regards,
Carsten

entry.title: Re: Material availability check in maintenance orders â€“ S...
entry.content:
Dear @saraserrano,

What you want is standard in Public Cloud but it works via an ATP check that updates dedicated material availability system statuses on the order (MSPT = Material shortage, MACM = Material committed, etc.). There is no customizing in Public Cloud to run this check live at order creation like in Private Cloud, instead you use Fiori apps and a scheduled job.

For maintenance orders you have dedicated material availability system statuses at order header, for example:

  • I0004 / MSPT - Material shortage
  • I0340 / MACM - Material committed
  • I0420 / MANC - Material availability not checked
  • I0485 / NMAT - No material components

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/6e25338332644773968319fe2d9b0dab.html

These statuses are:

  • Updated automatically when a material availability check is executed for the order
  • Visible in the order header (Change Maintenance Order app)

So your status Material shortage is exactly MSPT, which is set by the system when the check finds missing parts.

Where you see availability:

In Change Maintenance Order app:

  • You can Display Material Availability (IWBK) for the order.

 

  • After you run the check and save the order, if components are missing, the system sets MSPT Material shortage on the order header.

More details below in SAP Note:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003290734

In planning apps / backlog

Planners typically work from list/scheduling apps, where availability is summarized:

  • Manage Maintenance Notifications and Orders and Manage Maintenance Backlog

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/d8a94ddd0c514780a9836aa04524f96f.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/02eb6fdf89c147d7a51252c4b672bc6b.html

  • Resource scheduling apps (Manage Work Center Utilization, Manage Schedules, Maintenance Scheduling Board, Assign Maintenance Order Operations) show the Material Availability Status

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/8502afe99f714fde977d8344c340b34f.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/b2800e0b1d114308ad6e8e959ad2f476.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/03f2d1580255033be10000000a4450e5.html

This is typically where planners filter for Material Shortage to see all orders with missing stock.

How to get automatic Material shortage with standard. The key building block is the Fiori app Schedule Material Availability Check (F2465):

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/756fca81b45b4477a5f2060d36e4edde.html

 

  1. Open Schedule Material Availability Check
  2. Create a job using the template Material Availability Check for Maintenance Orders

 

  1. In the template you can:
    • Restrict by order type, phase etc.
  2. Define scheduling options for your scenario

 

When this job runs, it:

  • Performs an ATP check for all selected maintenance orders

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/756fca81b45b4477a5f2060d36e4edde.html

  • Updates the material availability system status on each order header
  • Makes that status visible:
    • in Change Maintenance Order app
    • in Manage Maintenance Backlog app

With this in place your requirement is covered in standard:

  • Materials not available ->job sets MSPT = Material shortage automatically.
  • Planners see this status directly in the order and in their backlogs.

Summary, with this you get:

  • Availability visible directly in the maintenance order
  • Automatic update of the status to Material shortage (MSPT) when parts are not available driven by the standard material availability check logic and scheduled job.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Beyond Revenue: Manage Your Pipeline by Quantity with SAPâ€™s New Volume Pipeline Manager
entry.content:
Why Volume Pipeline Manager?

Our traditional pipeline manager tracks revenue, but for bulk sellers, thatâ€™s only half the story. If your goal is to deliver 140,000 liters in Q4, you need visibility into quantities â€“ not just deal size. The Volume Pipeline Manager solves this by letting you manage your pipeline based on total quantity.

Prerequisites:

  • Define a tenant-wide default unit of measure (e.g., liters).
  • Set conversion rules to liters in product master if needed.
  • Maintain quantities in the default or a physically related unit of measure (e.g., gallons â†’ liters) per line item.

Key Capabilities

  • Interactive Bubble Chart: Visualize opportunities by quantity and time period for quick trend analysis.
  • Opportunity List View: Edit details like phase, forecast category, and close date directly.
  • Sales Unit/Territory Rollup [Only Sales Managers]: Break down pipeline by unit or territory for better forecasting.
  • Totals Breakdown [Only Sales Managers]: See aggregate totals by account, owner, document type, and sales phase.

Benefits

  • Improved Forecasting: Plan with confidence using accurate quantity-based insights.
  • Better Opportunity Management: Focus on high-volume deals that matter most.
  • Higher Productivity: Enable data-driven decisions and trend identification.

In Action: A Sales Managerâ€™s Day

Imagine youâ€™re a Sales Manager at Best Run Business reviewing your Q4 pipeline:

  1. Spot At-Risk Opportunities: Alpha Breweryâ€™s large deal needs attention â€“ the last customer interaction was weeks ago.
  2. Check Pipeline Coverage: Target is 140,000 liters; with 68,000 won and 150,000 committed, youâ€™re on track.
  3. Ensure Fair Distribution: Sarah may need coaching; Bellaâ€™s pipeline looks challenging.
  4. Drill into Product Demand: Emmanuel from production calls about the demand for Hefeweizen this month. A quick filter shows 14,000 liters committed between Alpha and Campon. 

Whatâ€™s Next for Volume Pipeline Manager?

Weâ€™re taking pipeline visibility to the next level. Upcoming enhancements include:

  • Target Visibility in Pipeline Manager: Compare pipeline against targets directly within the dashboard for instant performance tracking.
  • Totals Breakdown by Product and Product Group: Go beyond opportunity-level insights â€“ understand how each product contributes to your pipeline.

The Bottom Line

The Volume Pipeline Manager introduces a new way for sales managers and reps â€“ particularly those focused on a single product type â€“ to manage their pipeline. By shifting the emphasis from revenue to quantity, it adds a critical dimension for planning and execution. This capability was built in response to customer feedback, ensuring it solves real challenges for bulk sellers and delivers actionable insights for smarter, faster decisions.

entry.title: Modernizing Spartacus: Practical Gains from Angular 17â€“19 Control Flow and Deferred Rendering
entry.content:
Introduction :-

Spartacus storefronts often rely on dynamic components such as product detail sections, personalized CMS blocks, and multi-step checkout flows. Optimizing how and when these components render is essential for improving load times and maintaining an efficient user experience.

Angularâ€™s newer features offer several advantages:

  • Reduced initial bundle size

  • Improved rendering behavior

  • Cleaner and more maintainable templates

  • Better runtime performance and SSR compatibility

    These improvements directly support the performance requirements of modern Spartacus implementations.

    Deferred Loading in Angular :-

    Deferred loading enables parts of the UI to be loaded only when needed. Spartacus storefronts benefit significantly from this, especially for below-the-fold components or sections not required during initial paint.

    Deferring Spartacus Components :-

    Angular 17 Example :-

    Angular 17 introduced the @defer  syntax:

    @defer (on viewport) {
  <cx-product-reviews></cx-product-reviews>
} 
    @placeholder {
  <div class="skeleton skeleton-reviews"></div>
} 
    @error {
  <div>Unable to load reviews at this time.</div>
}

    This approach avoids loading non-critical components until they are visible.

    Angular 19 Enhancements :-

    Angular 19 keeps the same syntax but improves deferred view hydration, error handling, and prefetching behavior.

    @defer (on interaction) {
  <cx-order-history></cx-order-history>
} 
    @placeholder {
  <div>Loading...</div>
}

    These improvements are especially beneficial for Spartacus SSR deployments.

    Modern Angular Template Syntax :-

    Angularâ€™s new control flow syntax (@IF,  @FOR,  @switch) simplifies templates and delivers performance benefits over the traditional structural directives. These enhancements create more predictable rendering paths and reduce change detection overhead.

    Conditional Rendering with @IF :-

    Angular 17 Example :-

    @if (isLoggedIn$ | async) {
  <cx-navigation></cx-navigation>
} @else {
  <cx-login-register></cx-login-register>
}

    Angular 19 Behavior :-

    While the syntax remains the same, Angular 19 provides better diagnostics, stronger type-checking, and improved runtime performance.

    @if (cartLoaded$ | async) {
  <cx-cart-details></cx-cart-details>
} @else {
  <div class="loading">Loading cart...</div>
}

    Rendering Lists with @FOR :-

    Angular 17 Example :-

    @for (banner of banners; track banner.uid) {
  <cx-banner [banner]="banner"></cx-banner>
}

    Angular 19 Enhancements :-

    Angular 19 optimizes list diffing and supports more reliable hydration:

    @for (product of products; track product.code) {
  <cx-product-list-item [product]="product"></cx-product-list-item>
}
     
    Practical Example: Improving a Spartacus Product Detail Page :-

    Before (Traditional Structural Directives and Eager Loading) :-

    <cx-product-summary *ngIf="product$ | async as product"></cx-product-summary>

    <cx-product-images></cx-product-images>

    <cx-product-reviews></cx-product-reviews>

    After (Using Modern Template Syntax and Deferred Loading) :-

    @if (product$ | async as product) 
    {
  <cx-product-summary [product]="product"></cx-product-summary>
}

    <cx-product-images></cx-product-images>

    @defer (on viewport) {
  <cx-product-reviews></cx-product-reviews>
} 
    @placeholder {
  <div class="loading">Loading reviews...</div>
}

    This provides cleaner template structure and improves overall page performance, especially for initial load and Core Web Vitals.

    Conclusion :-

    Angularâ€™s modern features â€” particularly deferred loading and the updated template syntax â€” offer clear advantages for Spartacus implementations. While Angular 17 introduces these capabilities, Angular 19 refines them, providing better hydration, more efficient rendering, and stronger developer tooling.

    For Spartacus storefronts that rely heavily on dynamic content and complex templates, adopting these Angular improvements results in:

    • Faster initial load

    • Reduced JavaScript execution

    • Clearer and more maintainable code

    • More predictable SSR and hydration behavior

entry.title: From Tactical to Strategic: The Future of Procurement and Accounts Payable
entry.content:
From Tactical to Strategic: The Future of Procurement and Accounts Payable ðŸš€

In todayâ€™s rapidly evolving business landscape, the transformation of procurement and accounts payable (AP) functions is more than just a technological upgradeâ€”itâ€™s a strategic imperative. The recent episode of SAPâ€™s â€œThe Future of Procurementâ€ podcast, featuring Mike Jasper, Director of Transformation Product and Client Success at Extropy Advisors, dives deep into how organizations can shift from tactical operations to strategic value creation. Hereâ€™s what you need to know.

Shifting the Paradigm: From Manual Tasks to Strategic Impact ðŸ”„

Historically, procurement and AP have been viewed as transactional, paper-pushing departments. Mike highlights that while procurement has evolved from â€œpurchasing agentsâ€ focused on bids and POs, AP is still often stuck in manual, tactical activities. The key to unlocking strategic value? Automation. By automating invoice processing and data entry, AP teams can redirect their efforts toward activities that drive cost savings and business growth. This shift not only increases efficiency but also empowers AP to contribute to broader financial strategies.

The Power of Collaboration: Breaking Down Silos ðŸ¤

A recurring theme in the discussion is the importance of collaboration between procurement, AP, and finance. Mike and the panel emphasize that working together uncovers opportunities for working capital improvements, such as payment term extensions and early payment discounts. When departments align their KPIs and share data, they can collectively optimize supplier relationships, reduce late payments, and negotiate better terms. The creation of shared dashboards and procurement intelligence platforms fosters transparency and mutual understanding, driving both operational and strategic benefits.

Overcoming Resistance: Building Trust in Automation and AI ðŸ›¡ï¸

Change management is a critical challenge. Many AP professionals fear that automation and AI will lead to job loss or errors in financial reporting. Mike suggests a gradual approachâ€”automate in stages, track accuracy, and build trust by demonstrating that technology can handle routine tasks reliably. By quantifying success and focusing on exceptions, organizations can help AP teams see the value in shifting their focus from manual checks to strategic initiatives. AI is poised to revolutionize AP by enabling smarter data validation, predictive coding, and holistic financial insightsâ€”provided that organizations invest in clean, integrated data.

Forward-Looking Insights: The Road Ahead for AP and Procurement ðŸŒ

Looking to the future, Mike offers a bold prediction: AP and procurement may eventually merge into a single, strategic department. As automation and AI continue to advance, the boundaries between these functions will blur, enabling seamless collaboration and more impactful contributions to corporate strategy. The move toward digital payments, such as ACH and virtual cards, is accelerating, with the U.S. finally surpassing the halfway mark for non-check payments. However, thereâ€™s still work to be done to fully digitize and optimize payment processes.

Conclusion: Embracing Change for Lasting Value ðŸ’¡

The journey from tactical to strategic in procurement and AP is ongoing, but the destination promises greater efficiency, stronger supplier relationships, and enhanced business outcomes. Organizations that embrace automation, foster collaboration, and build trust in new technologies will be well-positioned to lead in the future of spend management. As Mike and the podcast panel remind us, the goal isnâ€™t to eliminate jobsâ€”itâ€™s to make them more impactful and rewarding. Now is the time to clean your POs, accelerate approvals, and realize those cost savings. Are you ready to be a change agent in your organization?

What are your thoughts on the future of procurement and AP? Share your experiences and join the conversation! Send your feedback, questions and topic ideas to TheFutureofProcurement@SAP.com

ðŸŒ OpenSAP: https://podcast.opensap.info/future-of-procurement/

ðŸŽ Apple Podcasts: https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/episode-23-from-tactical-to-strategic-with-mike-jasper/id1764078646?i=1000736234046

entry.title: Re: Monitor rating app
entry.content:
Hi Ankit, 

rating errors should be an exceptional case, especially in situations where the pricing configuration is not working as expected. 
Typically such problems are resolved in test systems before productive use of a pricing scheme.

Because of the worklist and the performance of the whole app, the restriction to 500 entries were chosen. Also, there are limitations regarding the number of retries you can trigger in one go. 
Do you expect that many of these usage records would run into a rating error? What would be the action to resolve the situation in your case?

Best regards, 
Carsten

entry.title: SAP Fiori development newsletter November 2025 (issue #37)
entry.content:
We are in the midst of â€œconference seasonâ€, so this means lots of great announcements about new innovations. See the events section below for details on the European and U.S. iterations.

If you are looking to try the latest AI-powered development tools, such as MCP servers, please join us at our next SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf on December 9. This is a great way to learn about where to focus your learning resources in 2026 and what tools you can use to accelerate your development projects.

For ongoing updates, I encourage you to join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable. Register online or email me for an invitation.

If you prefer to receive this in your inbox, please subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter.

Development news

Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal
In this 6-part series, Katrin Polloczek and Marcel Waechter provide a thorough look at the new SAP Fiori development portal, which replaces the Flexible Programming Model Explorer. The series covers building blocks, floor plans, extension options, custom pages, and how all these pieces fit together. Read more.

Installing SAPUI5 patches is now better in every respect
For years, the MIME repository has been the standard location for storing SAPUI5 runtime artifacts for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Although the MIME repository has served its purpose, many customers working with SAPUI5, especially system operators installing new SAPUI5 patches, face challenges. Now, the UI5 team introduces the SAPUI5 Runtime Repository to improve this in every respect: Angelika Kirilin explains.

Goodbye UI5 tooling - Hello UI5 CLI
Over the last decade, UI5 Tooling became the best-in-class tool to develop UI5 projects. It offers a range of features to make your life as a developer easy when serving and building projects. It turned out that the name UI5 Tooling led to much confusion and even support requests. The UI5 team settled for a new name "UI5 CLI" to align with industry best practices. See details.

Start your SAPUI5 coding journey in the SAPUI5 Demo Kit
The SAPUI5 SDK, or the Demo Kit, is the one-stop shop for modern developers who want to build state-of-the-art enterprise-grade SAP applications. Discover the features.

Streamlining local app previews: virtual endpoints for seamless development
In traditional app development setup, local app previews and testing rely heavily on physical sandbox files. While this method provides a level of consistency and stability, it often falls short in terms of up-to-dateness and maintenance effort. This post explores a new approach to local app previews and testing, which can now be virtually served by middleware. Learn more.

Events

Register for SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf (customers and sponsoring partners only): 
â€‹https://events.sap.com/eur-fiori-innovation-day-walldorf-2025/en_us/home.html

In case you missed it 

SAP TechEd summary articles
ASUG Tech Connect in Louisville, Kentucky, USA, had lots of great content on vibe coding, the evolution of SAP Fiori, and lots of hands-on sessions to test SAPâ€™s latest development tools and technologies.

The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build
If youâ€™re an SAPUI5 developer and couldnâ€™t attend SAP TechEd in Berlin, hereâ€™s one highlight you can watch as a replay: A deep dive session on â€œThe art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Buildâ€: https://www.sap.com/events/teched/virtual/flow/sap/tev25/catalog-virtual/page/catalog/session/1752166265407001r3vW

Back issues from the past year

entry.title: Re: 999 â€“ The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Hello Jack,

yes, correct, for the FIORI app postings (tcode starting with FBDC), the suppression/summarization BAdi will not be called. Here's the thing: there is also a field called EV_POSTNG_CTRL ("entry view posting control", I think I mentioned it in one of the comments above), which also controls the BSEG suppression/summarization for certain postings. So precisely for the tax payables FIORI app posting (transaction FBDC_P060), we added some code so that the FIORI app can pass us this ev_postng_ctrl field with a value of '2' (meaning "BSEG maximum summarization") so that we can perform a maximum summarization for this tax payables posting.

Hope you succeed with the incident!

Kind regards, 

Stefan

entry.title: The Future of SAP: Latest Trends Shaping the Industry in 2025
entry.content:
The SAP landscape is evolving rapidly. Here are the trends every aspiring consultant should know about:

1. AI & Machine Learning

AI is embedded in SAP solutions today. Consultants who understand AI-driven automation are highly sought after.

2. Cloud-First Deployments

S/4HANA Cloud is becoming standard. Cloud expertise is now a premium skill.

3. Sustainability & ESG Reporting

Organizations need consultants to help achieve ESG compliance. New specialization = new opportunities.

4. Low-Code/No-Code Solutions

Configuration skills are more valuable than ever. Rapid implementation is the new standard.

5. Cybersecurity & Data Privacy

Security expertise commands top dollar. Every project requires privacy compliance.

6. Real-Time Analytics

Business intelligence consultants are in high demand. Data storytelling is critical.

7. Extended Supply Chain Networks

Supply chain visibility is booming. Consultants here are building thriving careers.

8. Agile Methodologies

Waterfall is out. Agile, iterative approaches are the new normal.

The Bottom Line

The most valuable consultants in 2025 will specialize in these emerging areas. Don't just follow trendsâ€”master one and differentiate yourself.

Which trend excites you most? Which area do you want to specialize in? Drop your thoughts in the comments below!

Let's grow together in this dynamic industry. What's your next move? #                                                                                      #SAP #Trends2025 #CareerGrowth #SAPConsulting #AI #CloudComputing #DigitalTransformation

entry.title: Re: How do I connect a custom tables field with a system...
entry.content:
Not all tables are exposed for UDF linking by default. SAP occasionally adds new objects in new versions, but there is no guaranteee if/when they will add what you need. I believe you have two options:

  • Create addon - while addon is active, you can format a field to have a choose from list connection to a certain table
  • Use FMS - create a regulat text field and then link FMS to the field that returns the list from OLNG table
    • If you require additional control to stop users from entering any value, you can also create SP that blocks add/update if the value in your field is not on the list of values of OLNG table

entry.title: Pioneering Work on Enhancing Code Reasoning with Search and Self-Correction
entry.content:
Large language models (LLMs) for code generation and understanding can be boosted by training on search-like reasoning traces and by self-correction mechanisms. Recent work has framed code tasks as iterative decision processes, using fine-tuning or reinforcement learning (RL) to teach models to identify errors and explore alternative solutions. For example, Stream-of-Search (SoS) and Tree-of-Thoughts (ToT) reasoning organizes intermediate â€œthoughtsâ€ into a search tree, allowing LMs to branch on different solution paths and backtrack when needed[1][4]. As shown in the ToT schematic design, multiple partial solution â€œthoughtsâ€ are generated and evaluated, greatly improving performance on tasks requiring planning or search. Similarly, code models can be trained on annotated search traces, e.g. execution logs or error-flagged drafts, to internalize debugging strategies.

 

Our Work

Our team, the Research & Innovation team at Palo Alto led by Yaad Oren and Alexander Schaefer, collaborate with Dr. Noah Goodman's CoCoLab from Stanford HAI institution, exploring and bringing the pioneering work on the foundational reasoning capability enhancement of LLMs to SAP. Recently we got one paper accepted by NeurIPS 2025 Foundations of Reasoning workshop, titled by "Smaller Models, Smarter Rewards: A Two-Sided Approach to Process and Outcome Rewards" (arxiv link). The following is our abstract as a teaser:

Generating high-quality code remains a challenge for Large Language Models (LLMs). For the evolution of reasoning models on this task, reward models are a necessary intermediate step. These models judge outcomes or intermediate steps. Decoder-only transformer models can be turned into reward models by introducing a regression layer and supervised fine-tuning. While it is known that reflection capabilities generally increase with the size of a model, we want to investigate whether state-of-the-art small language models like the Phi-4 family can be turned into usable reward models blending the consideration of process rewards and outcome rewards.
Targeting this goal, we construct a dataset of code samples with correctness labels derived from the APPS coding challenge benchmark. We then train a value-head model to estimate the success probability of intermediate outputs. Our evaluation shows that small LLMs are capable of serving as effective reward models or code evaluation critics, successfully identifying correct solutions among multiple candidates. Using this critic, we achieve over a 20% improvement in the search capability of the most accurate code out of multiple generations.

 

Supervised Fine-Tuning on Search Traces

A key idea is to supervise models on entire search trajectories instead of only correct solutions. For example, Qin et al. train a backtracking model on DFS-generated reasoning traces and a direct model on final solutions[2]. They find this trace-based SFT can bias models into particular strategies: on CountDown puzzles the backtracking model overfits the training search path and underperforms, while on Sudoku it generalizes better. In general, learning from explicit annotated chains-of-thought (CoT) can encourage rich reasoning, but may also lock in suboptimal habits (e.g. verbosity or fixed search biases). Qin et al. show two pitfalls: (1) Prescribed search bias â€“ fixed traces can constrain exploration, and (2) Excessive verbosity â€“ writing out every step can discourage internal reasoning[2]. Notably, they observe that reinforcement learning fine-tuning can overcome these issues: a backtracking model fine-tuned with RL discovers new strategies and improves substantially, whereas a direct model improves one-shot accuracy but fares worse under parallel sampling[2].

Other supervised approaches include synthetically augmenting data with error annotations or â€˜hintsâ€™. For instance, Sahni et al. train models with error-infused examples (marking lines with potential bugs) to improve debugging[3]. In code repair tasks, models have been fine-tuned on (input, buggy code, fix) triplets to internalize common corrections. However, most of these rely on proprietary data or strong verifiers. Self-contained supervised traces for code are still scarce; researchers often generate them on-the-fly (e.g. solving puzzles to get traces) or use execution feedback. In our work, we also used Claude and Phi to generate similar reasoning hints to augment our training data.

 

Reinforcement Learning for Self-Correction

To leverage dynamic feedback, many recent works use reinforcement learning on self-generated data. One line of work (e.g. Stream-of-Search[4], SCoRe[5], CoCoS[6]) explicitly frames code generation as a multi-turn Markov decision process where the model can iteratively revise its code. These methods train the code model end-to-end using rewards that encourage fixing mistakes.

  • Stream-of-Search (Kanishk et al. 2024) proposes a unified search trace design, demonstrated through the game of Countdown. The streams of search logs the state transitions, actions and reward scores when making each computation step in the game. The highlight is that this scoring always considers the impact from different branching choices through backtracking.  Through pre-training a transformer-based language model on streams of search, and then applying further fine-tuning with policy improvement methods led to a significant improvement of correct solutions. 
  • SCoRe (Kumar et al. 2024) introduces a two-stage RL process for code and math. A base LLM first learns to produce correction traces by iterative self-evaluation (often in multiple turns) and then undergoes policy optimization using its own feedback. Simply fine-tuning on offline â€œcorrectionâ€ traces does not work well, so SCoRe employs online PPO with shaped rewards for partial correctness[5]. They report substantial gains on MATH and HumanEval pass@1 after RL. This shows small LMs can learn to â€œself-correctâ€ if trained under their own error distribution.
  • CoCoS (Cho et al. 2025) focuses on small open-source models. They propose an RL fine-tuning objective where each turnâ€™s reward reflects cumulative progress: the model is encouraged to maintain correct outputs and also to improve any incorrect outputs incrementally[6]. Specifically, CoCoS uses an accumulated reward (discounted sum over turns) and a progressive reward for fine-grained improvements, rather than just binary success. In experiments on MBPP and HumanEval with 1B models, CoCoS yields large improvements over baselines. The authors release code and RL data (on GitHub) enabling reproducibility[7].
  • RLEF (Gehring et al. 2024) frames code synthesis as an interactive RL problem. The model repeatedly proposes code, receives execution feedback (unit test results) as the environment response, and is updated via PPO to maximize passing tests. This end-to-end RL causes models to ground in test feedback rather than ignore it[8]. RLEF training on the CodeContests benchmark produces state-of-the-art solve rates with 8B and 70B models, while drastically reducing the number of samplings needed. Critically, RLEF models learn to adapt code based on errors â€“ e.g. using caches or fixing off-by-one errors â€“ without human hints. The gains generalize: after RLEF, models also improve on HumanEval+ and MBPP+ by leveraging feedback.
  • Satori (Shen et al. 2025) combines supervised format-tuning with RL. It first imitates a â€œChain-of-Action-Thoughtâ€ (COAT) format by training on synthetic multi-agent demonstrations, teaching the model to use special tokens like <|reflect|> or <|explore|>[9]. Then it applies RL with a Restart-and-Explore (RAE) strategy: the model is periodically reset to intermediate states (including failed ones) and trained to explore new branches, with rewards for eventual correctness and penalties for repeating mistakes[9][10]. The final 7B Satori model (based on Qwen) achieves SOTA on challenging math reasoning tasks, showing that an LLM can â€œinternalize searchâ€[9]. The full Satori code, model checkpoints, and RL data (including rollouts from RAE) are publicly released for community use.

These RL methods set examples for online self-improvement: the model generates its own traces (code attempts, feedback, or self-reflections), evaluates them via an automatic reward (tests or proxy reward models), and uses that to update its policy. In all cases, models get reward signals across multiple turns â€“ for example, RLEF only awards a final reward but uses intermediate test feedback as observations, while CoCoS and SCoRe explicitly shape rewards at each revision step. This multi-turn RL contrasts with one-off prompting: the model learns that reflecting on errors and branching can yield higher expected reward.

 

Empirical Gains and Benchmarks

Overall, trace-based training and self-correction in the mentioned work yield significant empirical improvements across diverse benchmarks:

  • Coding tasks: HumanEval/HumanEval+[11], APPS[12], TACO[13]
  • Mathematical reasoning: Sudoku[2]. MATH-500[15], GSM8K[16]

However, results also reveal nuances and limitations. The â€œbacktracking vs directâ€ study shows that task structure matters: on some problems (CountDown) naive backtracking hurt performance[2]. Many methods still rely on test or verifier oracles (e.g. to score branches), which will invalid this whole method when such oracles donâ€™t exist. Also, RL training can be sample-inefficient and sensitive to reward hacking.

 

Discussion and Outlook

Annotating search and correction steps enables deep reasoning in code LMs, but challenges remain. Key gaps include robust reward design, scaling to very large models, and generalizing for tasks with unclear oracles. Most existing methods focus on code generation. We hope future work in the community would apply more effort on code understanding (e.g. program analysis, code review, translation, documentation). It is also important to study the trade-offs: extensive backtracking can be quadratically expensive, and some tasks favor direct answering. Moreover, as the â€œwhen to backtrackâ€ analysis shows[2], blindly encouraging self-correction is not always beneficial.

Nonetheless, models that learn from their own mistakes via annotated traces or RL often outperform â€œsingle shotâ€ models. By combining supervision with tree-based reasoning traces through RL, systems can achieve autoregressive search capabilities without human prompts[9]. Overall, these advances point toward autonomous code agents that can plan, check, and correct â€“ closing the gap toward human-like programming workflows.

 

References

[1] Tree of Thoughts: Deliberate Problem Solving with Large Language Models

https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2305.10601v2

[2] To Backtrack or Not to Backtrack: When Sequential Search Limits Model Reasoning

https://arxiv.org/html/2504.07052v1

[3] Effective Large Language Model Debugging with Best-first Tree Search

https://arxiv.org/html/2407.19055v1

[4] Stream of Search (SoS): Learning to Search in Language

https://arxiv.org/abs/2404.03683

[5] Training Language Models to Self-Correct via Reinforcement Learning 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2409.12917

[6] Self-Correcting Code Generation Using Small Language Models

https://arxiv.org/html/2505.23060v1

[7] GitHub - jeonghun3572/CoCoS: This is the official implementation of the paper "Self-Correcting Code Generation Using Small Language Models"

https://github.com/jeonghun3572/CoCoS

[8] [2410.02089] RLEF: Grounding Code LLMs in Execution Feedback with Reinforcement Learning

https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2410.02089v2

[9] GitHub - satori-reasoning/Satori: [ICML 2025] Satori: Reinforcement Learning with Chain-of-Action-Thought Enhances LLM Reasoning via Autoregressive Search

https://github.com/satori-reasoning/Satori

entry.title: Issue with CDS Join for SD & FI Documents for Custom IRN RAP Application
entry.content:
Hello Expert,

I am working on a custom RAP based Fiori Elements Application for IRN and E-Way Bill Generation. Currently, we generate the IRN using the SD Document Type based on the CDS view I_BillingDocumentBasic.

As per the new requirement, we also need to include FI Documents, so we are using the CDS view I_JournalEntryItem. Our objective is to retrieve DG and DR documents using a UNION ALL, but we are facing an issue where some required fields are not appearing. I have attached a Code of the CDS view which we have  Developed.

Could anyone guide us on what might be causing the join issue or how we can achieve this requirement in our custom IRN application?

We have created two CDS views one is a join of the FI and SD document CDS views, and the another is the Backend CDS view used for IRN Generation where we fetch the Document Type.

Please find the attached First CDS view which has Join logic for both the SD and FI Document CDS views.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Billing and FICO Document Type Join'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_INV_FI_DOC_JOIN
  as select from I_BillingDocumentBasic     as VBRK

    inner join   I_BillingDocumentItemBasic as VBRP on VBRK.BillingDocument = VBRP.BillingDocument
{
  key VBRK.BillingDocument         as BillingDocument,
  key VBRP.BillingDocumentItem     as BillingDocumentItem,
      VBRK.CompanyCode             as CompanyCode,
      VBRK.BillingDocumentType     as BillingDocumentType,
      VBRK.AccountingExchangeRate  as AccountingExchangeRate,
      VBRK.DocumentReferenceID     as DocumentReferenceID,
      VBRK.BillingDocumentDate     as BillingDocumentDate,
      VBRK.CreationDate            as CreationDate,
      VBRK.PayerParty              as Customer,
      @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'TransactionCurrency'
      VBRK.TotalNetAmount          as TotalNetAmount,
      VBRK.TransactionCurrency     as TransactionCurrency,
      VBRP.Plant                   as Plant,
      VBRP.ReferenceSDDocument     as ReferenceSDDocument,
      VBRP.ReferenceSDDocumentItem as ReferenceSDDocumentItem,
      VBRP.Material                as Material,
      @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'BillingQuantityUnit'
      VBRP.BillingQuantity         as BillingQuantity,
      VBRP.BillingQuantityUnit     as BillingQuantityUnit,
      VBRP.BaseUnit                as BaseUnit,
      @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'TransactionCurrency'
      VBRP.NetAmount               as NetAmount
}
union all select from I_JournalEntry     as BKPF
  inner join          I_JournalEntryItem as ACDOCA on BKPF.AccountingDocument = ACDOCA.AccountingDocument
{
  key BKPF.AccountingDocument                             as BillingDocument,
  key cast(ACDOCA.AccountingDocumentItem as abap.char(6)) as BillingDocumentItem,
      BKPF.CompanyCode                                    as CompanyCode,
      BKPF.AccountingDocumentType                         as BillingDocumentType,
      BKPF.ExchangeRate                                   as AccountingExchangeRate,
      BKPF.DocumentReferenceID                            as DocumentReferenceID,
      BKPF. PostingDate                                   as BillingDocumentDate,
      ACDOCA.CreationDate                                 as CreationDate,
      ACDOCA.Customer                                     as Customer,
      ACDOCA.AmountInTransactionCurrency                  as TotalNetAmount,
      ACDOCA.TransactionCurrency                          as TransactionCurrency,
      ACDOCA.Plant                                        as Plant,
      BKPF.DocumentReferenceID                            as ReferenceSDDocument,
      ACDOCA.SourceReferenceDocumentItem                  as ReferenceSDDocumentItem,
      ACDOCA.Product                                      as Material,
      ACDOCA.Quantity                                     as BillingQuantity,
      ACDOCA.ReferenceQuantityUnit                        as BillingQuantityUnit,
      ACDOCA.BaseUnit                                     as BaseUnit,
      ACDOCA.AmountInTransactionCurrency                  as NetAmount
}

 

Here is the another CDS view where we are using this CDS view in the background for fetching the Document Type of SD & FI.

 

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'view entity to pick Invoice number'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZBR_INV_EDOC_PICK
       with parameters
       iv_fkdat : abap.dats
  as select from    ZI_INV_FI_DOC_JOIN            as _VBRK_BKPF

    left outer join I_ProductText                 as MAKT      on MAKT.Product = _VBRK_BKPF.Material
    left outer join I_Plant                       as t001w     on t001w.Plant = _VBRK_BKPF.Plant
    inner join      I_Customer                    as KNA1      on KNA1.Customer = _VBRK_BKPF.Customer
  
    inner join      ZR_EDOC_TYPE                  as EIDOCTYPE on  EIDOCTYPE.CompanyCode = _VBRK_BKPF.CompanyCode
                                                               and EIDOCTYPE.BillingType = _VBRK_BKPF.BillingDocumentType
  
    inner join      I_ProductPlantBasic           as marc      on  marc.Product = _VBRK_BKPF.Material
                                                               and marc.Plant   = _VBRK_BKPF.Plant
    inner join      I_CompanyCode                 as t001      on t001.CompanyCode = _VBRK_BKPF.CompanyCode
    left outer join I_IN_PlantBusinessPlaceDetail as PBplace   on  PBplace.Plant       = _VBRK_BKPF.Plant
                                                               and PBplace.CompanyCode = _VBRK_BKPF.CompanyCode
    left outer join I_IN_BusinessPlaceTaxDetail   as BBRANCH   on  BBRANCH.CompanyCode   = _VBRK_BKPF.CompanyCode
                                                               and BBRANCH.BusinessPlace = PBplace.BusinessPlace

  association [0..1] to I_Currency      as _TransactionCurrency on $projection.TransactionCurrency = _TransactionCurrency.Currency
  association [0..1] to I_UnitOfMeasure as _BillingQuantityUnit on $projection.BillingQuantityUnit = _BillingQuantityUnit.UnitOfMeasure
{
  key  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingDocument,
  key  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingDocumentItem,
       _VBRK_BKPF.CompanyCode,
       _VBRK_BKPF.BillingDocumentType,
       _VBRK_BKPF.AccountingExchangeRate,
       _VBRK_BKPF.DocumentReferenceID,
       _VBRK_BKPF.BillingDocumentDate,
       _VBRK_BKPF.CreationDate,
       @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'TransactionCurrency'
       _VBRK_BKPF.TotalNetAmount,
       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_TransactionCurrency'
       _VBRK_BKPF.TransactionCurrency,
       _VBRK_BKPF.Plant,
       _VBRK_BKPF.ReferenceSDDocument,
       _VBRK_BKPF.ReferenceSDDocumentItem,
       _VBRK_BKPF.Material,
       PBplace.BusinessPlace,
       MAKT.ProductName,
       @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'BillingQuantityUnit'
       _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantity,
       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_BillingQuantityUnit'
       _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit,
       _VBRK_BKPF.BaseUnit,
       @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'TransactionCurrency'
       _VBRK_BKPF.NetAmount,

       LIKP.DeliveryDocument,
       LIKP.ShipToParty,
       LIKP._ShipToParty.BPCustomerName                                                                                                                                             as LBPCustomerName,
       LIKP._ShipToParty.TaxNumber3                                                                                                                                                 as LTaxNumber3,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.CityName                                                                                                                     as LCityName,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.DistrictName                                                                                                                 as LDistrictName,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.PostalCode                                                                                                                   as LPostalCode,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetName                                                                                                                   as LCStreetName,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetPrefixName1                                                                                                            as LCStreetPrefixName1,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetPrefixName2                                                                                                            as LCStreetPrefixName2,
       LIKP._ShipToParty._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetSuffixName1                                                                                                            as LCStreetSuffixName1,
       t001w.PlantName,
       t001w.AddressID                                                                                                                                                              as PAddressID,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.AddresseeFullName,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.StreetName,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.CityName,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.DistrictName,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.PostalCode,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.StreetPrefixName1,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.StreetPrefixName2,
       t001w._StandardOrganizationAddress.StreetSuffixName1,
       BBRANCH.IN_GSTIdentificationNumber,
       KNA1.Customer,
       KNA1.BPCustomerName,
       KNA1.AddressID                                                                                                                                                               as CAddressID,
       KNA1.TaxNumber3                                                                                                                                                              as CTaxNumber3,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.CityName                                                                                                                                  as CCityName,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.DistrictName                                                                                                                              as CDistrictName,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.PostalCode                                                                                                                                as CPostalCode,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetName                                                                                                                                as CStreetName,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetPrefixName1                                                                                                                         as CStreetPrefixName1,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetPrefixName2                                                                                                                         as CStreetPrefixName2,
       KNA1._AddressDefaultRepresentation.StreetSuffixName1                                                                                                                         as CStreetSuffixName1,
       t001.CompanyCodeName,
       t001.AddressID                                                                                                                                                               as CCAddressID,
       t001._OrgAddressDefaultRprstn.CityName                                                                                                                                       as CCCityName,
       t001._OrgAddressDefaultRprstn.PostalCode                                                                                                                                     as CCPostalCode,
       t001._OrgAddressDefaultRprstn.StreetName                                                                                                                                     as CCStreetName,
       t001._OrgAddressDefaultRprstn.StreetPrefixName1                                                                                                                              as CCStreetPrefixName1,
       t001._OrgAddressDefaultRprstn.StreetPrefixName2                                                                                                                              as CCStreetPrefixName2,
       t001._OrgAddressDefaultRprstn.StreetSuffixName1                                                                                                                              as CCStreetSuffixName1,
       BBRANCH.IN_GSTIdentificationNumber                                                                                                                                           as CCGSTIN,
       EIDOCTYPE.BillingType,
       EIDOCTYPE.InvoiceType,
       EIDOCTYPE.IrnDocType,
       EIDOCTYPE.SupplyType,
       EIDOCTYPE.IrnApp,
       EIDOCTYPE.EwbApp,
       EIDOCTYPE.EwbDocType,
       EIDOCTYPE.ProcessType,

       _VBRK_BKPF.AccountingExchangeRate *  _VBRK_BKPF.AccountingExchangeRate                                                                                                       as exrate,
       @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'TransactionCurrency'
       cast ( cast (  _VBRK_BKPF.NetAmount as abap.dec( 15, 5 ) ) *  _VBRK_BKPF.AccountingExchangeRate as abap.curr(15,2) )                                                         as taxvalue,
       @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'TransactionCurrency'
       cast ( cast (  _VBRK_BKPF.NetAmount as abap.dec( 15, 5 ) ) *  _VBRK_BKPF.AccountingExchangeRate / cast( _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantity as abap.dec(13,5) )  as abap.curr(15,2 )) as unitprice,
       marc.ConsumptionTaxCtrlCode,
       case
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'kg'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit  = 'KG'
       then 'KGS'
       when _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'ea'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'EA'
       then 'NOS'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'pc'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'PC'
         or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'st'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'ST'
       then 'PCS'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'dr'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'DR'
       then 'DRM'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'ft2' or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'FT2'
       then 'SQF'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'g'   or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'G'
       then 'GMS'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'm2'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'M2'
       then 'SQM'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'm3'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'M3'
       then 'CBM'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'ml'  or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'ML'
       then 'MLT'
       when  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'paa' or  _VBRK_BKPF.BillingQuantityUnit = 'PAA'
       then 'PRS'
       else 'OTH'
       end                                                                                                                                                                          as zunit,
       _TransactionCurrency,
       _BillingQuantityUnit
}
where
  _VBRK_BKPF.CreationDate = $parameters.iv_fkdat

 

Thank you,

entry.title: Re: Unable to change status of an order to not relevant
entry.content:
Dear @Suvarna4,

The only supported ways to keep it out of Create Billing Documents (F0798) are:

  1. Delete the sales order (not possible here because you already had a billing document) or
  2. Reject all billing-relevant items with a rejection reason that has â€œNo Billingâ€ = ON in config.

Check in CBC:

  1. Configuration step Define Reasons for Rejection (102494)
  2. For the rejection reason you want to use (for example Order Cancelled due to Error)

 

    • Flag No Billing = ticked
      • This is what actually makes the items not copied to billing and removes them from the Create Billing Documents due list.

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3152233

If No Billing is not ticked, even a fully rejected order will still appear in the billing due list this is exactly what SAP Noteâ€™s 3102794 and 3471934 describe.

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3102794

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3471934

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: How to connect with SAP S/4HANA OData Services from SAP APIM? - OAuth 2.0 Based Authentication
entry.content:
@gabrielalberto_stein86

Let me assure you, it is extremely easy to implement. If you happen to have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me. 
The <Get> operation retrieves values from a Key Value Map (KVM), which I have created, called SAP_S4HANA_Credentials which has the Key as Username andPassword. 
usernameFromKVM is a private variable in your API proxy execution context. It holds the value of the Username key from the Key Value MapSAP_S4HANA_Credentials.
The prefix private. means the variable is scoped to the current flow execution and not exposed outside.


In short, usernameFromKVM is the variable that stores the SAP S/4HANA username retrieved from the Key Value Map SAP_S4HANA_Credentials. Itâ€™s used later in your API proxy for authentication or connection setup.

entry.title: Scale Pricing in Sales Based on Characteristic Value
entry.content:
Good evening,

Is it possible to do scale pricing (VK11) based on the value of a characteristic in the variant configurator in the sales order?

For example, the customer pays a fixed rate per size interval.

100-999 mm = â‚¬100

1000-1999mm = â‚¬175

2000-2500mm = â‚¬170.

In the variant configurator, we have the characteristic PRODUCT_SIZE, this is a field in which any value between 100 and 2500mm can be filled, to determine the product size. From a pricing point of view, the product size falls within one of the intervals above.

How can we make sure the correct sales price is selected based on the interval in which the value for PRODUCT_SIZE falls?

Is it possible to combine this with tier pricing/scales?

Thanks in advance,

Floyd

In short, usernameFromKVM is the variable that stores the SAP S/4HANA username retrieved from the Key Value Map SAP_S4HANA_Credentials. Itâ€™s used later in your API proxy for authentication or connection setup.

entry.title: SAP Ariba SLP - MDG attachment Integration - Making the Impossible Possible
entry.content:
The integration between SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP) and SAP Master Data Governance for Suppliers (MDG-S) enables extensive synchronization of supplier master data across both systems through choreographed business scenarios. The SLP-MDG integration supports bidirectional data exchange between SAP Ariba SLP and MDG-S, ensuring consistent supplier master data across both applications. If you would like to know the supported scenarios within this integration, refer to the standard documentation here

In this section, we will cover the details of integrating attachments from Ariba SLP into SAP MDG or SAP ERP systems.  Let's first discuss the potential documents a supplier will upload to Ariba SLP when they register or update their existing registration. 

  • Quality and other Certificates
  • Tax and Financial Documents
  • Supporting Documents that the buyer wants the supplier to upload
  • Contractual or Risk documents

Attachments in Ariba SLP are not restricted to the above documents it could be any Ariba acceptable format that pass the inbuilt Virus test while uploading on the SAP Business Network for Suppliers (which is the UI for the Supplier when trying to register to a Buyer's SLP) 

Secondly, attachment-related inputs can be collected in the Registration, Modular, and Qualification Questionnaire. The SAP Ariba SLP product team recommends receiving certifications with Validity dates through Modular questionnaires only. 

Lastly, Questionnaire respondents can add attachments to a supplier management questionnaire as a response to any of the following questions:

  • Answer type of Attachment.

  • Answer type of Certificate, where one of the certificate detail fields is an attachment field.

  • Any other answer type, with Participant can add additional comments and attachments set to Yes

In the first two cases, the attachment is a direct answer to the question. In the third case, the attachment is an optional addition to the response and can be added with or without a comment. For more details about the attachment sizes supported refer to the help documentation here.

With the above context now, lets see how we plan to achieve this attachment integration. There could be two sets of customers who are trying to achieve Attachment integration from SAP Ariba SLP to SAP MDG or SAP ERP system, 

  1. Customers who are already live with the SAP Ariba SLP integration with the SAP MDG or SAP ERP system using the standard Integration capabilities of SAP Integration Suite, Managed Gateway for Spend and Business Network (CIG) 
  2. Customers who are planning or currently implementing the Standard integration between SAP Ariba SLP and the MDG system. 

The integration package can work for both these customers, as we are not using the standard SAP Ariba CIG integration for attachments nor disrupting it. We will mainly be using SAP Ariba provided open APIs and SAP MDG standard APIs which make the package even more consumable and extensible for more scenarios if required. Moreover, we strongly encourage customers to opt for the SAP Ariba CIG-based standard integration between SAP Ariba SLP and MDG and additionally utilize this integration package to supplement the Standard integration with capability to integrate attachments between the systems.  

Let's now take a look at the architecture at a high level to see how to achieve this.

The Integration package, which we have developed and deployed for customers, basically looks for the latest created and changed suppliers in Ariba SLP by continuously checking at regular intervals, and if it finds suppliers that are approved and have a Registered status, With the help of SAP Ariba Open APIs, it transfers the attachment from these questionnaires to an SAP MDG or SAP ERP system, configurable based on customer requirements. 

This Integration package also delivers the ABAP code required to add the attachment to the SAP MDG Change request or the SAP ERP system Business Partner. 

Benefits of deploying this integration package for the Ariba SLP â†’ SAP MDG / SAP ERP BP Attachment Integration would be,

  • Fully automated attachment flow, zero manual intervention
  • Reduced onboarding cycle time, Accelerates Supplier Onboarding
  • Lower administrative overhead for Supplier Management teams in Customers
  • More consistent and complete supplier records, strengthening compliance and Auditability
  • Enhances Data Quality and Governance
  • Supports Multiple Integration Scenarios (Both SAP MDG and SAP ERP systems)

Customers have reported a 40-60% reduction in manual effort during supplier onboarding, based on the volume of attachments they handle. 

If you have any further questions, please leave a comment below or post your question to the community. We will be happy to get back to you.

entry.title: How does the Inventory Audit Report calculation work in SAP Business One?
entry.content:
Hello!

I am studying in depth how SAP Business One calculates and â€œfreezesâ€ quantities and values in the Inventory Audit Report.

I would like to understand what happens behind the scenes, specifically:

1. How does SAP â€œlockâ€ the quantity on a past date?
When I generate the report for a specific date (for example: 2024-10-30), it returns exactly the quantity I had in each warehouse on that date.

I would like to understand:

Which tables and fields does SAP use to reconstruct this historical stock balance?

Does it recalculate everything transaction by transaction, or is there any kind of snapshot?

Is there a table that stores frozen quantities, or is everything derived from historical documents only?

2. How does the system determine which items to include?
Does it include all items that had movements before the selected date?

Or only items with a non-zero balance?

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025

entry.title: SAP Champions
entry.content:
Who are SAP Champions?

SAP Champions are:

  • Proactive volunteers with a passion for SAP technologies.
  • Top contributors, leaders, and organizers within the SAP ecosystem.
  • Advocates of SAP communities.
  • Hands-on experts of an SAP product, service, and/or topics.

What do SAP Champions do?

SAP Champions help the SAP Community and its members:

  • Guide and support new members to help them get the most out of their community experience.
  • Share insights and expertise via blog posts, answering questions, drive or contribute to SAP Community group discussions.
  • Lead local SAP Community driven events such as an informal meetup or SAP Inside Track.

What is the difference between the SAP Champions and SAP Mentors programs?

The SAP Mentors share their knowledge and experience to SAP executives and product teams.
This provides an outside -> in view.
The SAP Champions advocate for SAP and SAP Community. They support us to share key messaging and to help drive software adoption in their networks.
This provides an inside -> out view.

Contact us

Looking for more information? For questions and comments about the SAP Champions, please contact sapchampions@sap.com.

Submit a nomination

SAP Champions can be nominated or self-nominated.
Nominated can include being approached proactively by the Community Programs team.
The selection process takes place by the community team, in cycles.

For more information, please contact sapchampions@sap.com.

What makes a great SAP Champion?

  • Top contributor: SAP Champions are top contributors to the SAP Community and ecosystem, serving as distinguished leaders and upholding community ideals and spirit. Traits include being a top influencer, leader, and organizer.
  • Advocate: Advocates and representatives of SAP communities â€“ whether through community.sap.com, related sites, social media, or in-person events. They demonstrate passion in everything they do, and inspire others to be like them.
  • Active SAP Community member: Must be a member of SAP Community for a minimum of one full year with an active membership, a profile with a recognizable display name, and featuring a photo.
    Have a robust reputation across SAP Community, including active participation in SAP Community groups (including location groups), questions and answers, blog posts and comments, and events.
  • Expert: Hands-on experts of an SAP product(s), service(s), and/or topic(s).
  • Professional: The span of membership must be marked with positive behavior and adherence to the community rules of engagement. The member's interactions with others must always be polite, friendly, and supportive; this extends to social media and both virtual and in-person events.
  • Continuous Learner: Someone who stays up-to-date and innovates.
  • Events-driven: Due to our renewed focus on events, in the previous one-year period, the member should have participated in several events including both online and in-person â€“ this includes hosting/speaking/attending.
  • Well-connected: Have a strong network and reputation across external sites/channels â€“ for example, LinkedIn.
  • Eligibility: Anyone not employed by an SAP competitor is eligible for the SAP Champions program. SAP Champions, however, may not be a member of an existing influencer program (e.g., SAP Mentors) or a special council dedicated to community strategy or activity.

Further resources

  • Current SAP Champions â€“ meet our amazing community leaders!
  • Become an Event Organizer â€“ for those interested, this guide is useful for those with a passion for proactively nurturing a local community.

entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now: I cannot save and delete a context help in Manager and Producer
entry.content:
Similar post 9 months ago How to resolve the "Save Failed" error in SAP Web ... - SAP Community   , I would guess you (or someone) is still editing it in the Fiori interface, which is where you normally edit Companion content anyway. In Manager, locate that object and see who has the object out for edit. If it's not you, Cancel Editing. If it is you, then I would recommend going to that screen in Fiori and seeing if you can edit it, then Save and Publish your changes, then leave the Edit mode and navigate away from the screen. That should release the write token. Then check Manager and refresh the screen to see if the object is Finished Editing, which it should be. 

If all else fails, I would Cancel Editing on the object in Manager and then see if you can edit it again in Fiori.

entry.title: Re: Planned Values in Cost based POC method of RA
entry.content: You can use standard RA configuration.  You are correct, choose Valuation Basis = S.  Then as actuals go over the planned costs it will use the actuals as the cost basis.  You will never go over 100% POC.

entry.title: Re: Forcing re-authentication into SuccessFators after ce...
entry.content:
Hello @katje_28 ,

At SAP SuccessFactors level it is possible to set a specific timeout period for users session. 

 The available configuration can be adjusted in provisioning, as per below:

  • Inactivity Time Before Session Timeout. Set the number of minutes, up to 30 minutes maximum, that a session can remain inactive before it expires. The default is 30 minutes.
    • By default, users will achieve timeout after 30 minutes without activity.
  • Warning Time Before Session Timeout. Set the number of minutes prior to timeout that a warning is displayed. The default is 10 minutes. If the configured value is greater than or equal to the Inactivity Time, the default value is used. 

Kindly note that,  the customized timeout period is only considered if there is at least one SuccessFactors tab open in the browser. Without any active SuccessFactors tab open the default 30 minute timeout will be considered.

If you don't have access to provisioning, you can open a SAP ticket under the component LOD-SF-PLT-PRVR.

To know more about this feature, please refer to KBA 2088893 - How to define the Session timeout period and timeout warning period for SuccessFactors Platform

Hope this can assist you on your query.

All the best,
Camila

entry.title: Re: Birthday Card
entry.content:
Hi @esinanya ,

Currently, SAP SuccessFactors birthday cards can only be enabled for managers via role-based permission, so manager will have access to the data of all their subordinates. Due to that, there ins't a way to restrict birthday cards to be displayed in case one specific employee does not want to share this data. The job will run and share the information for the manager of all their subordinates (as per configured in the RBP role used).

Documents for reference:

  • KBA 3116231 - Birthday and Work Anniversary Cards on the Home Page
  • KBA 3152871 - Prerequisites for showing Birthday and Work Anniversary cards in latest Homepage

If you would like to have this functionality included in a future release you can create an enhancement request, as per KBA 2090228. 

All the best,
Camila
